entries.text: Teleperformance is looking for talented Perl developers who are eager to join our team (10 developers).  We are a close-knit development group who live and breathe Perl and the open source philosophy.  We are located in Grandview Heights, Ohio, with easy access to the downtown area.
entries.title: Perl Developer - Teleperformance - Grandview Heights, Ohio (Columbus)

entries.text: Our yummy Perl codebase handles millions of emails in production each week! We're growing like crazy, doubling in revenue and size annually. We want you to join our team in Utah. Pass our "Perl Challenge" to win a $100 Amazon gift card and an interview. Hires will receive a sizable signing bonus.
entries.title: InsideSales.com - Pass our "Perl Challenge" & Win a $100 Amazon Gift Card

entries.text: Use Moose, DBIx::Class, Catalyst, AnyEvent and work in an dream office in Newport Beach office in California to  build and maintain our registry platform and services for Internet new Top Level Domains (nTLDs). Send your CV to jobs@uniregistry.link
entries.title: Work for Uniregistry, building and maintaining Internet new Top Level Domains

entries.author: graham_ollis
entries.text: Graham has recently adopted File::Which and posted about his plans for the module, in particular splitting out the pwhich script into a separate distribution, to minimise the dependencies for the main module.
entries.title: File::Which, pwhich and App::pwhich

entries.author: alex_balhatchet
entries.text: This month Nestoria tip their hat to Web::Query, a module for processing a web page in a jQuery stylee. Originally written by TOKUHIROM, but currently maintained by YANICK.
entries.title: Nestoria's module of the month: Web::Query

entries.author: miguel_prz
entries.text: Miguel Prz (NICEPERL)'s regular lists: Great modules released last week; MetaCPAN weekly report; StackOverflow Perl report.
entries.title: NICEPERL's lists

entries.author: david_farrell
entries.text: David introduces the Kelly criterion, a formula used to calculate what percentage of your bank you should stake. He's released Algorithm::Kelly to Kelly, if you're interested. The Kelly criterion is widely used by betting types (my missus and I used the Kelly criterion in the horse-betting system we ran a few years back. Not that we're betting types. Any more).
entries.title: Calculate Fortune's Formula with Perl

entries.author: john_napiorkowski
entries.text: John describes what's in the latest Catalyst releases. The dev release is codenamed Australorp, named after an Australian chicken breed!
entries.title: New stable and development Catalyst releases

entries.author: john_scoles
entries.text: Getting to the bottom of a problem with Amazon AWS. TL;DR: make sure Mozilla::CA is up to date.
entries.title: CA SSL HTTPs heck

entries.author: dave_cross
entries.text: Dave has shared three articles that he wrote in 2011, about writing a Modern Perl web app using DBIx::Class and Dancer.
entries.title: Three articles on Modern Perl web apps

entries.author: frew_schmidt
entries.text: Frew shares some tips on how to get DBIC schema to load faster.
entries.title: Faster DBIC Schemata

entries.author: brian_d_foy
entries.text: brian shares some of the ways you can work with gzip'd data in Perl, for example via the recently updated PerlIO::gzip, or using pipes.
entries.title: Gzipping data directly from Perl

entries.author: steven_haryanto
entries.text: Perlancar demonstrates his WWW::PAUSE::Simple module and associated pause script, which can be used to manage your PAUSE account from the command-line.
entries.title: Interacting with PAUSE using CLI

entries.author: nick_wellnhofer
entries.text: Nick shows how authors of XS modules can get Devel::Cover and coveralls.io to play together nicely with Travis.
entries.title: Howto: XS Coverage Reports on coveralls.io

entries.text: There are going to be several 'Master classes' on the day before YAPC::NA, and the 2 days after. 4 of the classes have been already published, 2 are still somewhere in the pipe, but if you attend YAPC::NA and want to attend any of the courses, you might want to plan your travel accordingly. ~szabgab (one of the trainers)
entries.title: YAPC::NA Master classes

entries.text: The Cleveland Perl mongers have risen from the ashes like a Phoenix; StylusEater shared some of their journey.
entries.title: Rebuilding Cleveland Perl Mongers

entries.text: GENEHACK tweeted to announce that the schedule for YAPC::NA 2015 has been posted.
entries.title: YAPC::NA schedule

entries.text: The German Perl workshop runs from the 6th to the 8th of May. If you're quick, you can still submit a talk proposal.
entries.title: German Perl Workshop 2015: CFP extended until March 30th 2015

entries.text: The Sydney mongers are meeting 14th April, and looking for speakers.
entries.title: Sydney.PM April meeting

entries.author: gabor_szabo
entries.text: Gabor has put together a page with some tips for promoting your Perl event.
entries.title: Promoting your Perl workshop or conference?

entries.text: Lazy deserialization of objects has been re-enabled in MoarVM, which should give "much better memory usage and speed when starting up a program that doesn't use every class there is". Also a rakudo release, some documentation improvements, and a bunch of other things too!
entries.title: Perl 6 weekly happenings

entries.author: mark_dominus
entries.text: Some excellent advice from Mark, about the right response when someone asks you to sign a contract with a clause that's only there because the lawyers wanted it. He followed it up with some examples.
entries.title: A public service announcement about contracts

entries.text: A survey of Ruby developers, which has been running since 2008. I like that for many questions it shows how the answers have changed over the years. TL;DR: vim is the most popular way to edit Ruby.
entries.title: Ruby survey results

entries.text: A talk from RubyConf last year, with lots of interesting observations of open source. I feel like I need to watch it again before I can distil it down any!
entries.title: The social coding contract

chapters.title: Not Perl, but may be of interest

entries.author: gabor_szabo
entries.text: In this article full of screenshots you'll see how to write a Perl script to send messages via Twitter.
entries.title: Sending Tweets from a Perl script

entries.author: gabor_szabo
entries.text: A screencast in which Gabor shows the first step in creating a clone of the search.cpan.org web site using PSGI and MetaCPAN as the back-end.
entries.title: Getting started - Create skeleton for the SCO clone application

entries.text: The beginning of a series of articles showing how to write a counter with various front-ends (e.g. command line, web) and various back-ends (plain text file, MongoDB, etc.)
entries.title: Counter Examples

header: The schedule for YAPC::NA is out and there are tons for good-looking talks!
Talking of talks, today's your last chance to submit something for the German Perl workshop.
There are also going to be additional training classes at YAPC::NA. See more info below. ~szabgab
subject: The YAPC::NA schedule is out!
